results.title: Phil's case
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Improving Performance”.
Phil works in despatch. Complaints about mistakes and late deliveries prompted his supervisor Kris to talk with him attempting to resolve the problem. Peter Quarry then assumes the role of supervisor using the three step approach.

results.title: Phiguring out acids and bases
results.creator_credit: Shane Mulcahy, Trish Pilley, Glen Foster, Deborah Lawther and Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education
results.brief_description: Examines the acids and bases in everyday use and develops the idea of ph measurment both quantitatively and qualitatively as a measure of concentration.This program presents historical developments of the proton/theory and pH notation. Practical applications of pH testing and adjustments are also covered.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Shane Mulcahy, Trish Pilley, Glen Foster, Deborah Lawther and Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education

results.title: Phi Phi Island after the Indian Ocean tsunami
results.brief_description: How the media produces news changed dramatically when bystanders captured the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami on handheld cameras. After obtaining the footage, news outlets circulated it around the globe. Today, social media allows spectators to share footage and images of world events instantly.

constellations_other.name: Representing disasters
constellations_other.description: The devastating Indian Ocean tsunami was captured by many people on personal devices and home cameras, with the footage broadcast to the world. The event also inspired feature films that are part of a long tradition of disaster films, which often push the boundaries of VFX.

constellations_other.name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
constellations_other.description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

results.title: Phenomena
results.brief_description: Creepy thriller from horror maestro Dario Argento features a strong performance from a very young Jennifer Connelly as an imperilled schoolgirl (also named Jennifer) who undergoes a series of frightening encounters whilst boarding at a Swiss finishing school. After experiencing nightmares that provide insight into a serial killer’s movements, Jennifer’s talent for communicating with insects links her to bug specialist Dr McGregor, with whom she aims to unmask the murderer. Engaging in the tropes of the genre - and using his trademark gore and gross-out aesthetics - Argento provides an array of thrills, scares and narrative twists all backed by a rock soundtrack. Uncut, uncensored widescreen edition. Also known as “Creepers” (US title).

results.title: Phenakistoscope discs
results.brief_description: The phenakistoscope is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc is fitted to the device and when seen through the slots, comes to life.

constellations_primary.name: Defying gravity (phenakistoscope)
constellations_primary.description: Walking on the walls and dancing on the ceiling.

results.description:
This is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc featuring a sequence of slightly different pictures is mounted on a handle. Around the disc’s rim, above the images, are equally spaced slots. Nothing magical happens when you spin the disc, but the images flicker to life when you peer through the slots at the disc’s reflection in a mirror.

Invented almost simultaneously in 1832 by Joseph Plateau in Brussels and Simon von Stampfer in Berlin, the phenakistoscope was an important predecessor of the zoetrope, and its infinitely looping animation is reminiscent of today’s GIFs.
description_for_label:
This is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc featuring a sequence of slightly different pictures is mounted on a handle. Nothing magical happens when you spin the disc, but the images flicker to life when you peer through the slots at the disc’s reflection in a mirror.

Invented almost simultaneously in 1832 by Joseph Plateau in Brussels and Simon von Stampfer in Berlin, the phenakistoscope was an important predecessor of the zoetrope, and its infinitely looping animation is reminiscent of today’s GIFs.

results.title: Phasing in metric designs
results.creator_credit: Stanley Marks, Stephen Cross, New Decade Productions and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Keys to Metrication”.
The changeover to metric design will normally be gradual and needs careful preparation. Imperial past can be incorporated in a metric environment of vice versa.

results.title: Phase one: Prince Charles Mountains
results.creator_credit: Roger Hayne, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows the work of a topographical and geological survey of the Prince Charles Mountains, Antarctica in 1969. Under summer conditions the land forms are visible, and valuable data is collected and evaluated.
